desc.size: cap 3 - 11 cm broad; stem 2 - 6 cm long, 10 - 25 mm thick.

part.partText: convex to broadly convex, sometimes becoming flat with age, white to pale gray. Surface smooth, dry, sometimes covered with fine brownish-gray fibers or scales in dry conditions. Flesh thick, white, unchanging when bruised or cut, may stain reddish-brown with age, not staining yellow with KOH.
free, crowded to close, narrow, pink when young eventually becoming blackish-brown.
may leave remnants on cap margin and forms a thin, membranous, quickly collapsing ring on the middle to upper part of stem that typically disappears with age.
stout, tapering to a pointed base, white, turning reddish-brown, smooth above ring, covered with fine fibers or hairs below; stuffed to hollow.

similarSpecies.comments: The most common, but not the only Agaricus species in lawns. Agaricus bitorquis has thicker flesh, a double ring, and doesn't have the bright pink gills when young. Other species have scaly or differently colored caps, or yellow staining, or stronger odors.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Common in lawns and grassy areas. Solitary to gregarious, sometimes in fairy rings, on soil. Soil saprobe that prefers lawns.

notes.comments: Was also called "common mushroom, champignon, or hot-bed mushroom" when it was thought to be the same species as the common store mushroom Agaricus bisporus, which is from the eastern Mediterranean. This and other urban mushrooms can accumulate chemicals, toxins, and heavy metals from the surrounding soil.

etymology.comments: Agaricon is an ancient Greek word for particular fungi, reportedly derived from Agara, the name of a Greek city which had abundant mushrooms nearby. Campestris is derived from the same word as campus, meaning a field.
